meeting_annotations.transcript: if an intervention could involve something on that scale of of human behavior, not like humans in their everyday life, well, I think that's really important, but maybe on those like more grandiose scale.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Charles E. Lewis
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think the one specialty that I've not seen mentioned that anyone has here and it's probably biased because I'm an Ebola guy and this has become critical in Ebola outbreak responses, medical anthropologist. I and actually someone that understands not only the human behavior, but how to look at individual behavior of specific populations and determine the interventions there. But I think that extends even to understanding rural culture and farmers and you know, I just think of the number of times being a city guy going on to farms and you know, they immediately know that and the distrust there. So, I think that that incorporation of behavior is critical to outbreak response.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Pilar Fernandez
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, and and on that I can tell you a story. I my work is very interdisciplinary because I'm trying to combine the the social dimension um and trying to understand that. So I've worked with economists, I've worked with um sociologist and most of my work on doing my PhD was in rural communities. And one of the things that we were not really paying attention to was the human movement or that it was a very cultural aspect. Uh so there was indigenous communities in the Gran Chaco region, which is really interesting if we talk about anthropogenic change because that's at the expansion of the agricultural frontier. So there's a lot of deforestation, human displacement happening. But one of the things that caught us our attention, we were like doing yearly uh entomological surveys to collect triatomines. And from one year to the next, people will move. Like they literally destroy their house, they're mud houses and build them somewhere else. We're like, we could not not find the house to do like a longitudinal surveillance. And and then we understood that it was just a cultural thing. It was also enhanced by the socio economic conditions. Um but it they were semi nomadic communities. So you cannot and that had a huge impact on the population of the vector because you didn't give enough time for the vector to um create high densities. But on the other side, you create really um the house are very precarious, so more opportunities for any bug outside bug to invade and have an infestation in that house. So it had a really interesting tradeoff just on without even thinking about how people get exposed to it, just on the vector population. And we were not really thinking about that because culturally to us it's like, well, you've been in this house, you're at least going to be there for a couple years. Uh but they would move frequently. And so we started working with sociologists trying to understand why because if we want to do an intervention and design an intervention strategy to spray the houses, we need to take into account that movement because it's not the same if you're spraying a house and it's going to last for the effect is going to last for this long, whether it's like, no, it's not going to last because in three months they're going to be somewhere else. Um so yeah, I do think that's a really key part of it and that's kind of what it actually drove my interest in trying to incorporate the human, the cultural and behavioral aspects.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Joyce Jose
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I think um knowing not only the virus is there, but what virus is there? What mutation? What variants specifically?
